question: Ic (gan) #### ut on dægræd þywende oxan to felda — I go out at dawn driving oxen to fields
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the first person singular form 'ga' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Ðu (gan) #### beforan Drihtnes ansyne his wegas gearwian — You go before the face of the Lord to prepare His ways
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the second person singular form 'gæst' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Verys lengtentima ond he (gan) #### to tune on .vii. idus Februarii — Fair is Spring and he goes to town on 7 to the ides of February
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the third person singular form 'gæþ' as the subject is 'he'

question: He ða gesceop of ðære eorðan eall nytencynn, and deorcynn, ealle ða ðe on feower fotum (gan) #### — He then created of earth all the race of cattle, and the brute race, all those which go on four feet
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the plural form 'gaþ' as the subject is 'ealle ða ðe on feower fotum'

question: Ic (gan) #### ða to Godes ðenunge ond ðaet folc gebletsode ond him Godes gerihtu dyde — I went then to God's ministry and blessed the people, and celebrated God's rights before them
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past first person singular form 'eode' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Þa þu gingre wære þu gertest þe ond (gan) #### þær þu woldest — When you were younger, you used to dress yourself and used to walk where you wished
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past second person singular form 'eodest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: He (gan) #### ofer sæ mid drium fotum ond he gestilde windas mid his hæse — He went over the sea with dry feet, and he stilled the winds by his command
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past third person singular form 'eode' as the subject is 'he'

question: Hie ða to ðam symle sittan (gan) #### wlance to wingedrince ealle his weagesiðas bealde byrnwiggende — Then they went to sit down to the feast, proud at the wine—drinking, all his woeful companions, bold byrnied warriors
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past plural form 'eodon' as the subject is 'hie'

question: Ic (gan) #### on minne bat ond rowe ut on þa ea ond weorpe min nett on þa ea — I go into my boat, row out on the water, and cast my net into the water
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the first person singular form 'ga' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Þu (gan) #### on þinum breoste and etst þa eorðan eallum dagum þines lifes — You go on your breast and eat the earth all the days of your life
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the second person singular form 'gæst' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Þa feng Æscwine to rice þæs cyn (gan) #### to Cerdice ond heold .ii. gear — Then Æscwine succeeded to the kingdom, the descent goes back to Cerdic, and held it 2 years
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the third person singular form 'gæþ' as the subject is 'þæs cyn'

question: Ne lifað na se man be hlafe anum ac lifað be ðam wordum ðe (gan) #### of Godes muðe — Man lives not by bread alone, but lives by the words which go from the mouth of God.
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the plural form 'gaþ' as the subject is 'ðam wordum'

question: Ic (gan) #### fram ðæm fæder ond com in ðisne middangeord efersonað — I went from the father and came in this world again
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past first person singular form 'eode' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Þa cwæð he: la freond hu—mæte (gan) #### ðu in — Then he said, 'Lo! Friend, in what manner went you in?'
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past second person singular form 'eodest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: He (gan) #### cucu and gesund into his byrgene — He went quick and whole into his grave
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past second person singular form 'eode' as the subject is 'he'

question: Þine syll (gan) #### ond ða assan wið hie læswodon; þa færlice comon Sabei ond hie ealle us benamon and ðine yrðlingas ofslogon — Your ploughs went and the asses grazed near; then suddenly Sabaeans came, and they took all of us and killed your plowman
explanation: Here 'gan' is in the past plural form 'eodon' as the subject is 'Þine syll'

question: Ond ic (don) #### æal swa ge biddaþ — And I will do all as you ask
explanation: Here 'don' is in the first person singular form 'do' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Hwæt (don) #### þu gif unclæne fiscas beoþ — What do you do if it is unclean fish?
explanation: Here 'don' is in the second person singular form 'dest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Gif esne (don) #### his rade þaes daeges, .vi. se wiþ dryhten gebete oþþe sine hyd — If a servant makes a journey of his own on that day, he shall pay 6 shillings compensation to his lord or undergo the lash
explanation: Here 'don' is in the third person singular form 'deþ' as the subject is 'esne'

question: Ne winne ge ongen ða ðe eow yfel (don) #### — Strive ye not against those who do you wrong
explanation: Here 'don' is in the plural form 'doþ' as the subject is 'ða ðe'

question: On þisse niht manega þingc ic (don) #### — I did many things on this night
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past first person singular form 'dyde' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Þu, cnapa, hwæt (don) #### todæg? — You, boy, what did you do today?
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past second person singular form 'dydest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Ða behydde Adam hine ond his wif eac swa (don) #### — Then Adam hid himself and his wife also did so
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past third person singular form 'dyde' as the subject is 'his wif'

question: Hu ne forealdodon þa gewritu þeah ond losodon þonecan þe hit wære swa some swa þa writeras (don) #### — Would not the writings nevertheless wax old and perish, as often as it was done, just as the writers did
explanation: Here 'don' is in the plural form 'dydon' as the subject is 'þa writeras'

question: Ic melke hie tweowa on dæg þærto ge cyse ge buteran ic (don) #### ond ic eom getrywe hlaforde minum — I milk them twice a day, then I do the cheese and the butter, and I am faithful to my lord
explanation: Here 'don' is in the first person singular form 'do' as the subject is 'ic'

question: Hwæt (don) #### þu be þinre huntunge? — What do you do about your catch?
explanation: Here 'don' is in the second person singular form 'dest' as the subject is 'þu'

question: Hi ða se hehsta Dema ædre mid elne onbryrde swa he (don) #### anra gehwylcne herbuendra þe hyne him to helpe seceð mid rǣde ond mid rihte geleafan — Then the highest judge swiftly inspired her with courage, as He does each person who seeks His help with reason and right belief
explanation: Here 'don' is in the third person singular form 'deþ' as the subject is 'he'

question: Ðæt cild weox swa swa oðre cild (don) #### — The child grew as other children do
explanation: Here 'don' is in the plural form 'doþ' as the subject is 'oðre cild'

question: Cumað ond geseoð ðone man ðe me sæde ealle ða ðing ic (don) #### — Come and see the man who said to me all the things I did
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past first person singular form 'dyde' as the subject is 'ic'

question: God cwæð to ðam wife: Hwi (don) #### ðu ðæt? Heo cwæð: Seo nædre bepæhte me and ic ætt. — God said to the woman, 'why did you do that?' She said, 'the snake deceived me and I ate'
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past second person singular form 'dydest' as the subject is 'ðu'

question: Frineð he for þære mænige hwær se man sie se ðe swa he ær on ðam beame (don) #### — He will ask before the multitude where that man may be who wanted to taste a bitter death just as he did on that tree before
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past third person singular form 'dyde' as the subject is 'he'

question: Gif we ænige bote gebidan scylan þonne mote we þæs to Gode earnian bet þonne we ær þysan (don) #### — If we shall experience any remedy, then we must deserve that of God better than we have previously done
explanation: Here 'don' is in the past plural form 'dydon' as the subject is 'we'
